H0.text: Host cell is the environment outside of which obligate intracellular parasites cannot be grown, preventing some bacteria from being cultured.

H1.text: Sponsor cell is the type of cell outside of which some bacteria cannot be cultured because they are obligate intracellular parasites and cannot be grown.

H2.text: Anchor cell is the host cell that obligate intracellular parasites, such as certain bacteria that cannot be cultured, cannot be grown outside.

H3.text: Brain cell is the type of cell outside of which some bacteria cannot be cultured because they are obligate intracellular parasites and cannot be grown.

A4.text: Obligate bacteria cannot survive without host cells.

A5.text: These bacteria cannot reproduce outside of the host cell because they lack the metabolic processes and enzymes needed to reproduce, which the host cell gives them.
